summary: Consider supporting `-webkit-fill-available` as an alias for `-moz-available` (extended to work in the height axis)
creator: dholbert@mozilla.com
commit_messages: Add an additional pref to prevent us from accepting `-webkit-fill-available` in properties beyond `width` and `height` (that's where we see it the most, and where I think we've got robust support)

Add support for the `stretch` keyword as the official name for the `-webkit-fill-available` behavior from (1), with `-webkit-fill-available` changing to be an alias (which I think is what [Chrome is also planning on doing](https://github.com/web-platform-tests/interop-2022-viewport/issues/18#issueco
Adjust `-moz-available` to also be an alias for `stretch` so that all three keywords do the same thing.
Clean up the now-unnecessary shim code added in (A)
Enable the pref that we added in (A) to fully-support the keyword, addressing remaining webcompat pain.
Handle 'stretch' and '-webkit-fill-available' as block-sizes, in nsIFrame::ComputeSize.
Land a pref-flip to enable `layout.css.webkit-fill-available.enabled` to enable support (in `width` and `height`)

summary: [Wayland] window.open top/left options aren't respected when generating a popup with explicit author-requested screen position
creator: dholbert@mozilla.com
commit_messages: (In reply to Darkspirit from comment #4)
I don't quite agree with this fwiw. This breaks a lot of legit popups (like e.g., PayPal / log in popups) that would be jarring to do in a separate tab / you'd lose a bunch of context.
IIUC, one can only spawn child windows (context menu, website info, bookmark menu, main menu) in relation to the main window (which has a taskbar icon).
Wayland apps can't position their windows, it's a core security feature of Wayland.
bug 1870955: Wayland apps can't position their windows, it's a core security feature of Wayland.
